Award.AwardTitle: OPUS: Understanding Ecosystem Processes in Response to Climate Variation in a Subalpine Forest
Award.AbstractNarration:
This project involves an integrative synthesis of 52 studies published by Dr. Monson over the past 14 years on how a subalpine forest exchanges carbon dioxide and water with the atmosphere. The project will enhance the utility of this body of work, improving its potential to inform stakeholders and land managers about the causes of several environmental challenges that have emerged in the Western US. These include an epidemic pine beetle outbreak, mass tree die-off due to persistent drought, high frequencies of wildfires, and uncertainty in the contribution of forests to regional carbon budgets. The investigator plans to: extract new, longer-term insights from a 14-year data set of forest carbon and water fluxes; use the longer-term insights to re-assess conclusions from the previously published papers; and disseminate the synthesis to those attempting to understand and manage forest ecosystems of the Western US. The synthesis will be conducted using an advanced computer modeling procedure known as Artificial Neural Network (ANN) analysis. The ANN analysis will be conducted in a manner that elucidates how changes in weather and climate affect the ability of the forest to exchange carbon and water with the atmosphere.

This project will support the work of a Graduate Research Assistant (GRA) to implement the ANN analysis. The results will be disseminated to the through: (1) an article intended for professional ecologists; (2) an invited Spotlight Article intended for foresters and land managers; (3) a book chapter intended for beginning graduate students; and (4) a chapter intended for college undergraduate students in a Wiki and hardbound book.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merit

In this project we used hindsight to evaluate 15 years of past research on the carbon dioxide, water vapor and energy exchanges between a mountain ecosystem in Colorado and the atmosphere. During that fifteen year period, the PI's research group at the University of Colorado has published over 50 peer-reviewed papers reporting on aspects of these ecosystem-atmosphere exchanges. The papers were published in serial fashion, one at a time, each dealing with specific aspects of the data record. This pattern of intellectual inquiry, and the publications that are produced, prevents the opportunity for integrative synthesis. With the funds fom this grant, we used an advanced artificial neural network analysis to conduct a formal, statistically valid, integration of these past studies, and discover synthetic patterns that can only emerge when all fifty-plus studies are considered together. Additionally, the PI used some of the resources to publish aspects of the synthesis in two different textbooks, which are intended for use by undergraduate and graduate students in the fields of plant ecology and climate change.

The results of the artificial neural network analysis revealed that air temperature is the primary climate determinant of a seasonal switch in the amount of carbon dioxide extracted from the atmosphere by this ecosystem. In this hindsight analysis, air temperature emerged as even more important than the timing of spring snow melt, a result that differs from our past one-at-a-time published results. The effect of air temperature on the amount of carbon dioxide extracted from the atmosphere, however, was sensitive secondarily to the timing of the seasonal snow melt. Warmer temperatures were associated with greater rates of forest carbon dioxide uptake dring the period when the snow was melting in the spring, but during the summer pre-monsoon and monsoon periods warmer temperatures were associated with lesser rates of carbon dioxide uptake. The inversion of this seasonal relationship was caused by a switch from lower soil respiration (carbon dioxide loss) rates during the spring, when snow cover keeps soil temperatures low, to higher soil respiration rates following snow melt, when soil temperatures increase. Consistent with our past studies, precipitation exerted an important, albeit secondary, control over rates of carbon dioxide uptake in the form of snowmelt water. Also consistent with our past studies, summer monsoon rain did not emerge as a relevant control, even when amounts were high during otherwise 'dry' years. This latter result, which was quantified formally in our formal hindsight analysis, was consistent with our past, albeit informal, analysis in the one-at-a-time studies. During summers with more frequent rain events, however, carbon diosixde extraction from the atmosphere was affected by the balance of tradeoff between the positive influence of high atmospheric humidity, and the negative influence of clouds and reduced solar photon flux densities. This impact of cloudiness on carbon dioxide uptake, during an otherwise 'wet year' was not apparent in our past one-at-a-time studies. This latter discovery has caused us to re-evaluate the degree to which 'wet summers' promote carbon dioxide uptake by this ecosystem. 

Support from this study allowed the PI to publish two text books, which included explicit chapters on the carbon dioxide, water vapor and energy exchanges between this forest ecosystem and the atmosphere:

Monson, R.K. and Baldocchi, D.D.  (2014)  Terrestrial Ecosystem-Atmosphere Interactions. Cambridge University Press, Cambridge, 507 pp.  ISBN 9781107040656

Monson, R.K. (ed.) (2014) Ecology and the Environment. Series: Plant Biology, Springer, Heidelberg, 659 pp. ISBN 978-1-4614-7500-2
